communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Between November 28, 2025 and February 17, 2026, all emails, messages (including MS Teams), documents, or other records:

* Created in reference to, or in the course of processing, Sound Transit Public Records Disclosure Request No. G000979-113025.
* Containing the text "kevin wallace", "muckrock", or "powerupdater", or variants thereof, or containing URLs starting with "https://kevin.wallace.seattle.wa.us/" or "https://www.muckrock.com/".

In the case of emails, messages, and other threaded or conversational media, I request the entire thread or conversation when any single message in the thread or conversation is responsive.

I am explicitly not at this time requesting the "POWERupdater" software itself.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kevin Wallace

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

any BWC footage from any of the responding officers to the accident that occurred on 12/2/2025 around 7:00 p.m. near the intersection of  Massachusetts Avenue and Osteen Road. The parties involved were: Steven Rodriguez, Tommie Thompson, Timothy Parsley, and Lawrence Wensil.  The vehicles involved were: 2011 White Ford Explorer, VIN: 1FMJK1H52BEF45896, Harley Davidson Motorcycle, VIN: 1HD1CLP165K401235, 2019 Black Dodge Durango, VIN 1C4RDJDG7KC821428 and a Hyundai sedan.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Michelle Pelaez

communications.subject: Louisiana Public Records Law Request: Claudette Teresa Christy Police Record

Sincerely,

Eric Lashawn Payne Jr

title: CPRA Request: Flock Safety ALPR Records

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: CPRA Request: Flock Safety ALPR Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide copies of the following records from January 1, 2024, to the date of this request, unless a different timeframe is specified below:

I. Contracts, Funding, and Acquisition
Please provide documents for Items 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 from the period between the inception of the agency's relationship with Flock Group, Inc. (Flock Safety) and the present.
1. All contracts, licensing agreements, software-as-a-service (SaaS) subscriptions, Master Services Agreements (MSA), and Memoranda of Understanding (MOU) between the San Bruno Police Department (or the City of San Bruno acting on its behalf) and Flock Group, Inc. (Flock Safety).
2. Any amendments, renewals, extensions, or change orders to the agreements described in Item 1.
3. All purchase orders, invoices, and records of payments made to Flock Safety.
4. Records identifying the specific funding sources used for these systems (e.g., General Fund, asset forfeiture funds, state/federal grants, or private donations).
5. All internal memos, proposals, or staff reports discussing the acquisition, approval, placement, or pilot programs for Flock ALPR cameras.

II. Policy, Privacy, and Governance
6. The current ALPR Usage and Privacy Policy, as required by California Civil Code § 1798.90.51, including data retention schedules and access protocols.
7. Annual ALPR audit reports required by Civil Code § 1798.90.53.
8. Training materials, policies, or directives provided to sworn and civilian personnel regarding authorized use of the Flock system.
9. Any Surveillance Use Policies, Anticipated Surveillance Impact Reports, or Privacy Impact Assessments related to ALPR technology generally or Flock Safety specifically.
10. The San Bruno Police Department's records about agendas, minutes, or logs of meetings regarding the contracting, implementation, or security of Flock Safety cameras.
11. Documentation regarding public notification of surveillance, including signage standards, maps provided to the public, or press releases.
12. Any complaints or grievances received from the public regarding ALPR camera placement or data use.

III. Operational and Technical Data
13. A list of all current and planned locations of Flock Safety ALPR cameras deployed by the San Bruno Police Department (including those in unincorporated areas and contract cities), including: coordinates or intersection descriptions, installation dates, the specific purpose for each location (e.g., traffic monitoring, crime prevention), camera model numbers/hardware specifications.
14. The names and titles of the specific System Administrators or managers responsible for the oversight of the Flock Safety system (e.g., Professional Services Division Commander).

IV. Usage Data, Sharing, and Audits
15. The total number of license plates scanned (read) by the San Bruno Police Department's Flock cameras, aggregated by month.
16. All existing audit or access logs generated by the Flock Safety system documenting queries/searches conducted by agency personnel. I request that personally identifiable information of non-employee subjects be redacted rather than the records withheld. Please include: date and time of search, reason for search (as entered into the system audit trail), and the agency or unit of the officer conducting the search.
17. Records regarding the sharing of ALPR data with the Northern California Regional Intelligence Center (NCRIC), including but not limited to: 
- Any MOUs, data-sharing agreements, or network-participation terms governing the transmission of the San Bruno Police Department's ALPR data to NCRIC; 
- Records describing the technical mechanism by which data is shared (e.g., automatic real-time feed, batch upload, or query-based access);
- Any policies, directives, or written guidance governing what restrictions, if any, the San Bruno Police Department places on NCRIC's downstream use or further dissemination of San Bruno Police Department-origin ALPR data;
- Records of any requests received from NCRIC (or through NCRIC from other agencies) to query or obtain San Bruno Police Department ALPR data, and the San Bruno Police Department's responses to such requests.
18. A list of all "hot lists" (e.g., stolen vehicles, Amber alerts) or custom "hot lists" currently integrated into the San Bruno Police Department Flock system.
19. A list of all outside agencies (local, state, and federal) that the San Bruno Police Department shares Flock data with, and a list of all outside agencies from whom the San Bruno Police Department receives Flock data, including but not limited to access provided through Flock Safety's real-time network sharing features (e.g., the platform previously known as TALON), and any data-sharing agreements, MOUs, or network participation terms governing such access.
20. Any statistical reports or evaluations generated by the department or Flock Safety regarding the efficacy of the system (e.g., number of vehicles recovered, arrests made attributable to ALPR hits).
21. Records of any unauthorized access, data breaches, or security incidents involving ALPR data.

V. Communication
22. All written communications (emails and attachments) between San Bruno Police Department employees and representatives of Flock Safety (email domain @flocksafety.com), excluding routine IT troubleshooting tickets.
23. All written communications with other law enforcement agencies or federal partners regarding requests to access or share San Bruno Police Department Flock data.

If you determine that any portion of the requested records is exempt from disclosure, please redact only those portions and provide the remainder of the record. For any redaction or denial, please cite the specific legal exemption justifying the withholding, as required by Government Code § 7922.540.

Given that this request is made in the public interest by a student journalist writing for Scot Scoop, I respectfully request a waiver or reduction of any fees associated with this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Maximus Kwan

title: CPRA Request: Flock Safety ALPR Records

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: CPRA Request: Flock Safety ALPR Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide copies of the following records from January 1, 2024, to the date of this request, unless a different timeframe is specified below:

I. Contracts, Funding, and Acquisition
Please provide documents for Items 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 from the period between the inception of the agency's relationship with Flock Group, Inc. (Flock Safety) and the present.
1. All contracts, licensing agreements, software-as-a-service (SaaS) subscriptions, Master Services Agreements (MSA), and Memoranda of Understanding (MOU) between the Daly City Police Department (or the City of Daly City acting on its behalf) and Flock Group, Inc. (Flock Safety).
2. Any amendments, renewals, extensions, or change orders to the agreements described in Item 1.
3. All purchase orders, invoices, and records of payments made to Flock Safety.
4. Records identifying the specific funding sources used for these systems (e.g., General Fund, asset forfeiture funds, state/federal grants, or private donations).
5. All internal memos, proposals, or staff reports discussing the acquisition, approval, placement, or pilot programs for Flock ALPR cameras.

II. Policy, Privacy, and Governance
6. The current ALPR Usage and Privacy Policy, as required by California Civil Code § 1798.90.51, including data retention schedules and access protocols.
7. Annual ALPR audit reports required by Civil Code § 1798.90.53.
8. Training materials, policies, or directives provided to sworn and civilian personnel regarding authorized use of the Flock system.
9. Any Surveillance Use Policies, Anticipated Surveillance Impact Reports, or Privacy Impact Assessments related to ALPR technology generally or Flock Safety specifically.
10. The Daly City Police Department's records about agendas, minutes, or logs of meetings regarding the contracting, implementation, or security of Flock Safety cameras.
11. Documentation regarding public notification of surveillance, including signage standards, maps provided to the public, or press releases.
12. Any complaints or grievances received from the public regarding ALPR camera placement or data use.

III. Operational and Technical Data
13. A list of all current and planned locations of Flock Safety ALPR cameras deployed by the Daly City Police Department (including those in unincorporated areas and contract cities), including: coordinates or intersection descriptions, installation dates, the specific purpose for each location (e.g., traffic monitoring, crime prevention), camera model numbers/hardware specifications.
14. The names and titles of the specific System Administrators or managers responsible for the oversight of the Flock Safety system (e.g., Professional Services Division Commander).

IV. Usage Data, Sharing, and Audits
15. The total number of license plates scanned (read) by the Daly City Police Department's Flock cameras, aggregated by month.
16. All existing audit or access logs generated by the Flock Safety system documenting queries/searches conducted by agency personnel. I request that personally identifiable information of non-employee subjects be redacted rather than the records withheld. Please include: date and time of search, reason for search (as entered into the system audit trail), and the agency or unit of the officer conducting the search.
17. Records regarding the sharing of ALPR data with the Northern California Regional Intelligence Center (NCRIC), including but not limited to: 
- Any MOUs, data-sharing agreements, or network-participation terms governing the transmission of the Daly City Police Department's ALPR data to NCRIC; 
- Records describing the technical mechanism by which data is shared (e.g., automatic real-time feed, batch upload, or query-based access);
- Any policies, directives, or written guidance governing what restrictions, if any, the Daly City Police Department places on NCRIC's downstream use or further dissemination of Daly City Police Department-origin ALPR data;
- Records of any requests received from NCRIC (or through NCRIC from other agencies) to query or obtain Daly City Police Department ALPR data, and the Daly City Police Department's responses to such requests.
18. A list of all "hot lists" (e.g., stolen vehicles, Amber alerts) or custom "hot lists" currently integrated into the Daly City Police Department Flock system.
19. A list of all outside agencies (local, state, and federal) that the Daly City Police Department shares Flock data with, and a list of all outside agencies from whom the Daly City Police Department receives Flock data, including but not limited to access provided through Flock Safety's real-time network sharing features (e.g., the platform previously known as TALON), and any data-sharing agreements, MOUs, or network participation terms governing such access.
20. Any statistical reports or evaluations generated by the department or Flock Safety regarding the efficacy of the system (e.g., number of vehicles recovered, arrests made attributable to ALPR hits).
21. Records of any unauthorized access, data breaches, or security incidents involving ALPR data.

V. Communication
22. All written communications (emails and attachments) between Daly City Police Department employees and representatives of Flock Safety (email domain @flocksafety.com), excluding routine IT troubleshooting tickets.
23. All written communications with other law enforcement agencies or federal partners regarding requests to access or share Daly City Police Department Flock data.

If you determine that any portion of the requested records is exempt from disclosure, please redact only those portions and provide the remainder of the record. For any redaction or denial, please cite the specific legal exemption justifying the withholding, as required by Government Code § 7922.540.

Given that this request is made in the public interest by a student journalist writing for Scot Scoop, I respectfully request a waiver or reduction of any fees associated with this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Maximus Kwan

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide copies of the following records from January 1, 2024, to the date of this request, unless a different timeframe is specified below:

17. Records regarding the sharing of ALPR data with the Northern California Regional Intelligence Center (NCRIC), including but not limited to: 
- Any MOUs, data-sharing agreements, or network-participation terms governing the transmission of the Burlingame Police Department's ALPR data to NCRIC; 
- Records describing the technical mechanism by which data is shared (e.g., automatic real-time feed, batch upload, or query-based access);
- Any policies, directives, or written guidance governing what restrictions, if any, the Burlingame Police Department places on NCRIC's downstream use or further dissemination of Burlingame Police Department-origin ALPR data;
- Records of any requests received from NCRIC (or through NCRIC from other agencies) to query or obtain Burlingame Police Department ALPR data, and the Burlingame Police Department's responses to such requests.
18. A list of all "hot lists" (e.g., stolen vehicles, Amber alerts) or custom "hot lists" currently integrated into the Burlingame Police Department Flock system.
19. A list of all outside agencies (local, state, and federal) that the Burlingame Police Department shares Flock data with, and a list of all outside agencies from whom the Burlingame Police Department receives Flock data, including but not limited to access provided through Flock Safety's real-time network sharing features (e.g., the platform previously known as TALON), and any data-sharing agreements, MOUs, or network participation terms governing such access.
20. Any statistical reports or evaluations generated by the department or Flock Safety regarding the efficacy of the system (e.g., number of vehicles recovered, arrests made attributable to ALPR hits).
21. Records of any unauthorized access, data breaches, or security incidents involving ALPR data.

V. Communication
22. All written communications (emails and attachments) between Burlingame Police Department employees and representatives of Flock Safety (email domain @flocksafety.com), excluding routine IT troubleshooting tickets.
23. All written communications with other law enforcement agencies or federal partners regarding requests to access or share Burlingame Police Department Flock data.

If you determine that any portion of the requested records is exempt from disclosure, please redact only those portions and provide the remainder of the record. For any redaction or denial, please cite the specific legal exemption justifying the withholding, as required by Government Code § 7922.540.

Given that this request is made in the public interest by a student journalist writing for Scot Scoop, I respectfully request a waiver or reduction of any fees associated with this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Maximus Kwan

title: CPRA Request: Flock Safety ALPR Records

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: CPRA Request: Flock Safety ALPR Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Unless a different timeframe is specified below, this request covers records from January 1, 2024, to the date of this request.

I. ALPR Data Intake from Specified Agencies
1. All records identifying the law enforcement agencies that currently transmit, upload, or otherwise provide Automated License Plate Reader (ALPR) data to NCRIC, including the method of transmission for each agency (e.g., automatic real-time feed, batch upload, or query-based access).
2. All Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs), data-sharing agreements, network-participation terms, or other written agreements between NCRIC and the following agencies governing the sharing or receipt of ALPR data:
a. San Mateo County Sheriff's Office (SMCSO)
b. Belmont Police Department (Belmont, California)
c. Burlingame Police Department (Burlingame, California)
d. Daly City Police Department (Daly City, California)
e. San Bruno Police Department (San Bruno, California)
3. Records identifying the volume of ALPR plate reads received by NCRIC from each of the five agencies listed in Item 2, aggregated by month.
4. Records identifying the ALPR technology vendors or platforms (e.g., Flock Safety, Vigilant Solutions/Motorola, Rekor, etc.) from which NCRIC receives or ingests data, and whether the data from each of the five agencies listed in Item 2 arrives through a vendor-operated platform or through a direct agency feed.

II. Query and Access Logs
5. All existing audit or access logs generated by NCRIC's ALPR system(s) documenting queries or searches of ALPR data originating from each of the following agencies, with results provided separately for each agency:
a. San Mateo County Sheriff's Office
b. Belmont Police Department
c. Burlingame Police Department
d. Daly City Police Department
e. San Bruno Police Department
For each query record, I request: the date and time of the query, the agency or unit of the individual conducting the query, and the stated purpose or justification for the query as recorded in the system. I request that personally identifiable information of non-employee query subjects be redacted rather than the records withheld in their entirety.
6. Records identifying the total number of queries made against NCRIC's ALPR database(s) by all users, aggregated by month, and broken down by querying agency where such records exist.
7. A list of all agencies, units, or task forces (local, state, and federal) whose personnel currently have authorized access to query NCRIC's ALPR database(s).

III. Downstream Sharing and Federal Access
8. All records documenting instances in which ALPR data held by NCRIC (including data originating from any of the five agencies listed in Item 2) was provided to, accessed by, or queried by personnel of any federal agency, including but not limited to:
a. U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)
b. Homeland Security Investigations (HSI)
c. U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP)
d. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI)
e. Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA)
f. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF)
g. U.S. Marshals Service
9. All records documenting instances in which intelligence products, analytical reports, or investigative leads derived in whole or in part from ALPR data were disseminated by NCRIC to any federal agency or to personnel assigned to a federal task force, including joint task forces operating under federal direction.
10. Any policies, directives, or written guidance that govern or restrict the downstream dissemination of ALPR data or ALPR-derived intelligence by NCRIC to federal agencies, including any restrictions imposed by the originating local agency (e.g., any of the five agencies listed in Item 2).
11. Any policies or directives addressing NCRIC's obligations under California's sanctuary or data-privacy laws (including the California Values Act, SB 54, and Civil Code § 1798.90.51 et seq.) as they relate to the sharing of ALPR data with federal immigration enforcement agencies.

IV. Policy, Retention, and Oversight
12. NCRIC's current ALPR Usage and Privacy Policy, as required by California Civil Code § 1798.90.51, including data retention schedules.
13. All annual audit reports of NCRIC's ALPR program required by California Civil Code § 1798.90.53, from January 1, 2023, to the present.
14. Records identifying the current data retention period for ALPR data held by NCRIC, and any records reflecting changes to the retention period during the timeframe of this request.
15. Records of any unauthorized access, data breaches, policy violations, or security incidents involving ALPR data held by NCRIC.
16. Records of any complaints or inquiries received from members of the public, advocacy organizations, or elected officials regarding NCRIC's ALPR data practices.

V. Hot Lists and Alerting
17. A list of all categories of "hot lists" (e.g., stolen vehicles, AMBER alerts, BOLO lists) currently integrated into or compared against NCRIC's ALPR database(s), including the source of each hot list.
18. Any records describing the use of custom or locally generated hot lists, including the criteria or authorization process for creating such lists.

VI. Governance and Oversight Structure
19. The names and titles of NCRIC personnel responsible for administering, overseeing, or auditing the ALPR program.
20. Agendas, minutes, or summaries of any meetings of NCRIC's Privacy, Civil Rights, and Civil Liberties Advisory Committee (or equivalent oversight body) at which ALPR data practices were discussed, from January 1, 2023, to the present.

If you determine that any portion of the requested records is exempt from disclosure, I ask that you redact only those portions and provide the remainder of the record. For any redaction or denial, please cite the specific legal exemption justifying the withholding, as required by Government Code § 7922.540.

Given that this request is made in the public interest by a student journalist writing for Scot Scoop, I respectfully request a waiver or reduction of any fees associated with this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Maximus Kwan
